bibl.title: Moy Wah v. J. C. Drake. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, Northern WESTERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Moy Wah for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Comes now the above named Moy Wah, and for his petition and complaint in writing for a writ of habeas corpus, on oath respect- fully shows to this court:

That on or about the 22nd day of January, A.D., 1892, he left the City of Portland, Oregon, where he had resided for 14 years immediately prior to said time, and had been for Four years last past engaged in the merchantile business, for Hong Kong, Chi- na, and that he did, prior to taking his said departure, appear before one J.E. Marks, a Notary Public and then and there sub- scribe and make the certificate hereunto attached a copy marked as exhibit "A" and making and forming a part of this his petition.

2. That all the facts and circumstances as set forth an said statement are true; that petitioner for over four years last past been actively engaged as a Chinese merchant in Portland, Oregon, and was at said time doing business at 168 Fifth Street, and was a member 22nd of the firm of Gum Wing Chung & Co., and as a member of said firm still having and retaining all of his said interests in said business, which was the sum of $1200, and still having and re- ceiving his share of the profits from said business and was at said time a bona fide owner and holder of about a one-fifth in- terest in said business, the capital stock of said business being $6,000 and your petitioner being one of the partners in said busi- ness; that your petitioner fully and completely relied upon said J. E. Marks as an attorney at law for the proper wording and making of said certificate and fully believes that the same fully

and completely complies with the law as in such cases made and provided; that the said certificate is attached a photograph of your petitioner, which photograph petitioner had taken for the purpose of having same attached to said certificate.; and petition- er further states that at said time he did obtain the statement of persons well and favorable known to him, one of said persons be- ing Capt. Thomas Hawks, who was for a number of years a policeman upon the beat upon which petitioner's business was located and frequently met the said Hawks, and that afterwards said Thomas Hawks was deputy tax collector in the city of Portland and had called upon this petitioner and collected taxes, and that the said Capt. Thomas Hawks did sign said statement attached to said cer- tificate, and that he is the same Thomas Hawks whose affidavit is hereunto attached, and that the said certificate of petitiner is a correct copy of petitioner's certificate with the exception of the photograph and att and marked as exhibit "A" as aforesaid.

Our petitioner further states that he did, on or about the 22nd day of January, 1892, take his departure for Hong Kong, Chi- na, and and did there remain and visit with his parents, rela- tives and friends, and transact his business and the business of his said firm, which was that of viewing, examining and ascertain- ing the prices of goods and making arrangements for the buying and shipping from the manufacturers in China; that thereafter, he did, about the 10th day of January, 1893, take passage on the steamer Victoria at Hong Kong, China, to return to the United States of America, and that he did pay his fareor said passage and did re- turn to and was landed at the steamboat wharf at Tacoma, and did then and there present his certificate and request to be landed; that one Plummer, representing himself to be a deputy collector, did, without any cause, right, or authority, and without explain-

ing or making known to this petitioner any of his reasons for not allowing him to land, refuse to allow your petitioner to land, al- though your petitioner had in all ways and manner complied with the laws of the United State of America, and did offer and was willing to produce the witnesses who signed said statement to said certificate, together with other witnesses both white and Chinese who knew and would identify him your petitioner as having in the city of Portland for a number of years last past, and as being a good, honest, upright and bona fide merchant in said city and a member of the firm doing business at H S Fifth St street, in the city of Portland, Oregon, but regardless of said of- fer, said Plummer made to your petitioner or to one Moy Yuck who well understands and speaks the English language, no satisfactory explanation whatsoever, and gave him no reason whatsoever for re- fusing to admit your petitioner, but did take from your petitioner his certificate with his photograph thereto attached, and the statement as thereto attached signed by the petitioner and re- speciive parties as set forth in exhibit "A", and did refuse to re- turn same to your petitioner and has ever since said tine retained same and does still continue to retain same, and your petitioner has not had or seen the same since said time, and the same is still had and retained by said Plummer or the Collector of Customs or some one under him, without the consent and against the wish and protest of petitioner, and petitioner further states that on the evening of the 8th day of May, 1893 about the hour of 3 o'clock, he was informed that Moy Wah the said steamer Victoria, with a large num- ber of Chinese passengers, about two hundred in number, nearly all of whome were strangers to this petitioner, and Moy Wah whome he knew nothing, and had no relation, would, at 4 o'clock on the morning of the 9th inst. loose from the wharf at Tacoma, and be cleared

and return upon her return trip to Hong Kong; and that your petitioner, together with his two companions, who are likewise merchants and who likewise ask for a writ of habeas corpus, would be forcibly, unjustly, unlawfully and illegally, and without any cause whatsoever, and without being informed as to any cause, com- pelled to remain upon said vessel and thus be compelled to return to Hong Kong. That your petitioner did cause to be made, diligent search and inquiry to find and ascertain the whereabouts of this Honorable Court to apply to it for a writ of habeas corpus, and did apply in the above court to the Commissioner of your Honorable Court for said writ, which was refused by said Commissioner for the reason that he had no authority to issue said writ, and that your petitioner was then compelled to resort to and did apply to the Superior Court of Pierce County, washington, for a writ of habeas corpus, setting forth the facts and circumstances, which application was consider- ed by the Court and by said Court, the Honorable W. H. Pritchard the granted, said writ in the words following to-wit: "Let the writ of habeas corpus and the warrant issue as prayed for in the within complaint and petition. May 8, 1893. W.H. Pritchard, Judge." That the said W. H. Pritchard was, at that time one of the duly elected and qualified and acting judges of the Superior Court of the State of washington, for the County of Pierce, said cause being number 9689 as appears by the record and files of said Superior Court of the State of Washington, for the county of Pierce; and that thereupon the clerk of said court did, under the seal of said court, issue said writ of habeas corpus and warrant to for the arrest of said Moy Nah as prayed for in said petition, and under said writ the sheriff did proceed to the steamboat wharf and to the steamer Victoris, and ask for the said Moy Wah who was called for by the captain of said steamer, and without any fur- ther orders and without any protest, ordered the said Moy Wah to go ashore, which said Moy Wah did then and thereupon do, without any protest or resistance or proceedings of any kind of rep-

resentative whatsoever of the United States of America; and that the said captain did thereafter appear before the said Superior Court and make and file his written answer to said writ of habeas corpus, and that then and is thereupon, and upon the filing of said answer, the said petitioner Moy Wah by his counsel demurred there to, which demurrer was by the court sustained and after hearing the respective counsel and arguments of same, the said Moy Wah was then and thereupon by said court, in the presence of the officers of the government discharged by the said Superior Court which he wasbe- fore, all of which proceedings, including the said petition, or- der of said court, writ of habeas corpus, warrant of arrest and return of the officers upon it andsaid process, answer of the said captain, the ruling and order of the court and record of the pro- ceedings of the respective parties, appears of record in the rec- ords of the Superior Court of the State of washington for the County of Pierce in cause number 9689 as given, made and filed therein.

That immediately upon the discharge of said Moy Wah as afore- said he was then and thereupon arrested charged with being ille- gally in the United States of America, and was taken before Honor- able Miles E. Clifford, Court Commissioner of theCircuit Court of the United States at Tacoma, who proceeded to inquire into said cause, and did refuse to allow said petitioner to be turned over to the United States marshall to be returned to said steamer Vic- toria, which was still at the wharf at Tacoma and ordered that said petitioner be held and returned by the United States marshall for a hearing before him, which hearing was fixed for the 17th day of May, 1893 at 10 o'clock in the forenoon, at which hearing evi- dence was introduced for the respective parties and your said petitioner was by said Commissioner ordered deported, from which or- der, judgment and ruling, with the consent of the United States attorney waiving all forms and regularities of giving notice, an

appeal was taken to this Honorable Court, and upon the question of jurisdiction of the United States Commissioner being, by the United States Attorney raised, this Honorable Court did, on the 5th day of June, 1893, order that your said petitioner be turned over to and placed in custody of the United States marshal J. C. Drake, who proceeded and took your said petitioner in possession, and now forcibly, knowingly, unlawfully, without just cause is now holding, detaining and retaining and keeping in confinement your said petitioner, although he has demanded his liberty, refused to recognize said demands, and still continues to hold, retain, de- tain and deprive this petitioner, of his liberty, and your peti- tioner states that he can, if allowed a hearing before this Hon- orable Court, show that he has fully and completely complied with all the laws of the United States and the rules and regulations thereof, and regardless of said compliance, the Collector of Cus- toms did wilfully, knowingly, arbitrarily, unjustly and unlawful- ly, and without any cause, right or authority, refuse to admit your petitioner and allow him to land, and that your said peti- tioner is rightfully and justly entitled to land andbe and remain in the United States and go his way to his former residence as here- tofore stated and resume his business at the city of Portland.

Your petitioner further states that he is at this time im- prisoned at the United States penitentiary at McNeil's Island, in Pierce County, Washington, and within the jurisdiction of this court; that he is not detained by virtue of any order or process issued by the United States Court, nor by virtue of any execution or any other process, judgment, decree or final order of any state court or other court other than herein stated as aforesaid: and that he is not held for the violation of any law; rule or regula tion or in punishment for any crime by him committed.

Petitioner further states that he is advised by Marshall K. Snell, his counsel, who resides at Tacoma, Pierce County, Wash- ington, and who is a counsellor of this court, having and holding a certificate authorizing him to practice in and before this court, that such imprisonment is illegal for the reason and facts as herein set forth, and that under andby virtue of the laws of the United States a writ of habeas Corpus directed to the said United States marshal should be issued by this Honorable Court to bring before it your petitioner.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner ever prays and hereby applies for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for the purpose of an inquiry into the cause of such imprisonment and restraint, and delivering him threr- from and discharging him from custody.
Dates this 6th day of June, 1893
Moy Wah (Chinese Signature)
Petitioner.
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, WESTERN DIVISION
In the Matter of the Application of for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Moy Wah (Chinese signature) being first duly sworn on his oath deposes and says:-

That I am the petitioner named in the foregoing petition; that I have heard the same read and interpreted to me and know the contents thereof; that all matters therein stated other than the proceedings in court as therein recited, are to my personal knowledge true, and as to those matters I verily believe them to be be true, which matters referred to as stated upon information and belief, are the proceedings in court had and referred to in said petition.
Moy Wah (Chinese signature)
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 6th day of June, 1893
Charles A Murray
Notary Public in and for Pierce County, Residing at Tacoma, Washington.
